archetypes.name: Limits to Growth (Limits to Success)
archetypes.rationale: The model shows a growth engine where New Contributors can become Experienced Contributors and then Core Developers through skill development and promotion. However, Core Developers leaving through turnover creates a balancing feedback that limits growth. The implicit knowledge transfer from Core Developers creates a reinforcing loop for growth, but this same resource is being depleted through turnover.

variables.name: Burnout Pressure
variables.description: Pressure on Core Developers from mentoring and knowledge transfer activities
variables.rationale: Represents the constraint that limits the growth engine - as Core Developers spend more time mentoring, they experience increased pressure that can lead to turnover

variables.name: Mentoring Workload
variables.description: The amount of mentoring required based on the ratio of New Contributors to Core Developers
variables.rationale: Quantifies the demand on Core Developers' time for knowledge transfer activities

connections.rationale: More New Contributors increases the mentoring demand on Core Developers
More Core Developers reduces the per-developer mentoring workload
Higher mentoring workload increases burnout pressure on Core Developers
Increased burnout pressure leads to higher turnover of Core Developers, completing the balancing loop

archetypes.name: Shifting the Burden
archetypes.rationale: The model shows two knowledge transfer mechanisms: Implicit Knowledge Transfer (mentorship) and Explicit Knowledge Transfer (documentation). This suggests a potential pattern where the organization might rely more on the quick-fix of mentorship (symptomatic solution) rather than investing in the fundamental solution of better documentation. Mentorship provides immediate benefits but may not scale as well as documentation.

variables.name: Documentation Investment
variables.description: Rate of investment in creating and maintaining documentation
variables.rationale: Represents the fundamental solution that could reduce dependency on mentorship

variables.name: Documentation Quality
variables.description: The quality and completeness of documentation available to contributors
variables.rationale: Accumulates the effects of documentation investment over time

variables.name: Mentorship Dependency
variables.description: Degree to which the organization relies on mentorship versus documentation
variables.rationale: Represents the shifting burden pattern where quick fixes reduce motivation for fundamental solutions

connections.rationale: Better documentation quality improves explicit knowledge transfer effectiveness
Successful mentorship reinforces dependency on this approach
Higher dependency on mentorship reduces motivation to invest in documentation (the fundamental solution)
Increasing burnout pressure creates awareness of the need for fundamental solutions like documentation

archetypes.name: Success to the Successful
archetypes.rationale: The model shows Core Developers driving Implicit Knowledge Transfer, which then improves Skill up and Promotion Rate. This creates a reinforcing loop where successful Core Developers (those who remain) get to shape more new contributors, potentially creating a pattern where certain developers or approaches become dominant while others are excluded. The existing structure suggests that Core Developers have disproportionate influence over who succeeds.

variables.name: Contributor Diversity
variables.description: Diversity of backgrounds, approaches, and perspectives among contributors
variables.rationale: Represents the variety that could be reduced by success-to-the-successful dynamics

variables.name: Approach Homogenization
variables.description: Degree to which contributor approaches become standardized around Core Developer preferences
variables.rationale: Measures the reduction in diversity as successful approaches dominate

connections.rationale: More Core Developers with established approaches increases homogenization pressure
Increased homogenization reduces contributor diversity over time
Higher diversity enables more innovation and adaptation to new challenges
Innovation potential contributes to long-term project sustainability
